comments.text:
OK, first things first:

(1) You ABSOLUTELY MUST have strong C (not C++) coding skills to even consider taking this class!  Either CS107 or CS110 (or both) is recommended.  If you do not, you willbe in for a world of hurt,to quote the legendary Mehran Sahami.  The programming assignments, while not incredibly difficult, do require a significant amount of C coding, and you will be doing a lot of debugging with gdb, valgrind, and network analyzer tools like Wireshark.

(2) I would also recommend taking CS161 before this class, as some of the material on routing (e.g. Bellman-Ford, Dijkstra) will make more sense if you have a good background in graph traversal algorithms.

(3)  Last of all, this class has a heavy workload -- sometimes cruelly so.  There are many types of work (8 weeks of video lectures/quizzes, 4 programming assignments, 2 written homeworks, and 2 exams) and theyre often packed together with similar due dates. In addition, the teaching staff is fond of sadistic exercises like holding (mandatory) class the day of the midterm (why?? is this really necessary??).  Oh, and the exams are VERY difficult.

That all being said: CS144 is a valuable course, and youll learn lots of the intricate -- but fundamental -- details of what makes the Internet work: Ethernet, TCP/IP, routing, physical/link layer (what is WiFi? how does the router in your closet work? how do packets flow between different hosts?) and of course security. It forces you to examine and think critically about key Internet protocols that we use every day, and often take for granted.  The course staff were also extremely helpful and responsive on Piazza. I found McKeowns teaching style to be much more clear and understandable than Levis, but your mileage may vary.

This class is a LOT of work, and you will learn a LOT about networking and the internet in this class.

As of Autumn 2013, Phil Levis and Nick McKeown teach this class viaflipped classroom. This unfortunately results in much more work than a normal lecture style class. Every week you are required to watch 10-12 videos (ranging from 15-30 minutes long), and every video has a short 3-5 question quiz on its material. The quiz is supposed to check that you watched the video, but in reality the quiz questions are as difficult as exam questions. You need to have a mastery of the material in order to answer them correctly. Some questions require you to lookup (google or RFC) information not covered in the video. You only get 2 attempts at each question, and overall the quizzes account for 10% of your grade. This was incredibly frustrating for me, and was by far my biggest complaint about the class. Videos + quizzes alone took me about 8-10 hours per week.

There are 4 labs (coding projects) and 2 homeworks. Labs 1 and 4 were the biggest; they each took me about 25-30 hours to complete. Labs 2 and 3 took me around 15 hours. The homeworks took about 10 hours each.

And best of all, even though it's flipped classroom, lecture is not optional! We were required to attend 16 of the 20 lectures in the quarter.

Despite all these complaints, there were a lot of positives. Phil and Nick are very smart and very knowledgeable. Lecture was almost always useful, and most of the videos are very informative. The labs do a good job of reinforcing the material, and the homeworks are good review for the midterm/final. Speaking of exams, the midterm and final are not easy - I would recommend studying and fully understanding the homeworks and online quizzes.

So all in all, this class took up most of my time the quarter I took it. I wish they were more upfront about the time requirement, but at the end of the class you will have a very deep understanding of the internet, from how ethernet and wi-fi work to how IP packets are routed, to how TCP gives us reliable data transfer, and more. And that's pretty cool.
Useful class, get to read RFCs and implement static/dynamic routing, and NAT functionality

I found this class a bit painful. When all was said and done, it was worth it, but it wasn't exactly pleasant.

To me, networking is interesting by virtue of its infrastructural component -- unlike most areas in computer science, you get to think on a bigger scale than what goes on inside your box. As in, the world big. 

I think all the coolest stuff comes at that level, including DNS and all the funky organizational structure that exists to support the Internet. Most of the class doesn't really deal with this, though...much more time is spent on the details of protocol operation. Which is, honestly, about as exciting as it sounds. Certainly, I now appreciate the power and difficulty of protocol engineering, but a few to many lectures were spent rolling through the details of protocols. Often, actually, lectures kind of devolved into long strings of protocol details with little in the way of broader significance.

Levis is organized and intelligent. He prides himself on clarity of presentation, which he may or may not have really had -- again, after the 50th detail about TCP, clarity isn't as important as simply keeping the classes attention. Phil's approach is a bit too placid to hold most students for 75 minutes, so lectures could end up a little dry. From talking to students from previous years, I get the impression that Mazieres brought an impassioned attitude that might've made things more interesting, even if they were less clear. 

Assignments are pretty hard, often because there's a lot to do, there's unresolved ambiguity about what needs to be done, and the programs are difficult to debug. The whole get-it-from-the-RFC thing is cool, but its mixed with a sort of half-specification at the assignment or reference solution level that doesn't leave you the freedom the RFC intends to while not providing the clairty an assignment handout could. This is one of the most active classes on Piazza as a result. 

The writing assignments were presented without any guidance, which was a problem because, actually, Levis wanted a VERY SPECIFIC THING, and graded based on how close the assignment fulfilled the criteria defining his ideal. His ideal was not unreasonable, but it was a pain that he didn't make it clear until far into the quarter. The writing assignments were valuable, but more guidance --  and a point to useful resources (and, maybe topics that were closer to actual class material) potentially could have been nice.

The TA's were very good, though there were some unfortunate big grading mistakes.

Overall, it's empowering to know what all those funky acronyms mean, and the infrastructural picture is deep and interesting (thank you, Jon Peterson!). The class is worthwhile, but only if you're willing to wade through the pain even when the class is less interesting.

Good luck, and bookmark Piazza.

Great Class. I really enjoyed it. Programming assignment do take time. But are manageable if you follow the instruction on lab page and rfc. As others said tests are pretty tricky. But almost half of the questions on exam were on just TCP working or TCP congestion control and how other network principles affect TCP. Lot of material is covered in the lectures but most of it is informational and not tested. True/False questions are asked and zero marks are awarded if you get correct answer but absolutely incorrect reasoning. One advice will be think of every topic taught in class and see if it can have something to solve the question if you have no clue. One question was related to cryptography, dns and nat i.e  its difficult to get clue to answer such questions. Prof Phil Levis is great. He introduced writing assignments this quarter. They are good but were painful and time consuming for me. Overall great class for any networking enthusiast.

Solid class. Lectures were a little slow at times, but they brought up interesting examples (like how Skype works). There are five programming assignments, all in C. I thought the third (static router) and fifth (network address translator) assignments were the most time consuming, although they each definitely have their own challenges. When you get them to work, you feel like the God of the Internet.

The tests were pretty tricky. I would recommend doing more than just re-reading lecture slides to prepare for them.

This was genuinely the most awesome class I've ever taken. Mazieres and Levis organize the class incredibly well and are always on top things, and their lectures are baller. I'm going to burn the recorded lectures to a DVD so once I have kids I can force them to watch it. 

Start the programming assignments early, I alloted time to rewrite each assignment once and that helped a lot. Study like hell for the tests, they're incredibly fair but also incredibly hard. As long as you're comfortable in C and have an interest in the source material (you'll know within the first few lectures), you'll be fine.

144 teaches you everything you need to know about networking. It is true that the assignments can be a bit frustrating, but once you figured out what to do, you will get it done very fast. Each of the assignment takes around 10-15 hours to complete and they come out around once every two weeks. So the workload is not high at all.

This is a great class. It is a great introduction to Computer Networks and after this class you will always be able to make sense of any high level talks/papers on the subject. 
The programming assignments are in C. The programming assignments require a good mix of coding ability and thinking. You have to think hard over many implementation issues and once you do that, you will never forget those concepts. It does get monotonous at times, with all that you are doing is stuffing packets with values (you will know what I mean ;) , but then you are doing the real deal with ARP,IP, Ethernet, TCP,UDP headers and what not. So in summary, its a great class and necessary for every software engineer !

144 is a pretty valuable class and will give you a really good understanding of how networks work. The projects are useful and pretty cool - you start by implementing TCP and later get to build a basic router. The projects are not too time consuming, tho they are in C/C++ which some people may find more difficult... The annoying aspect of the class weresurprise in-class quizzes- they counted for 10% of the final grade and I guess the idea behind them was to get people to come to class / do the readings. The quizzes weren't  too difficult, but watching lectures on SCPD instead of coming to class wasn't an option ...

Good class.  assignments can be frustrating beause they expect you to figure out how to do things from RFC rather than providing you with guides.  Although this is how things would be done in the real world, it is not necessarily an effective use of learning time.  Overall, this was a good class, the 5-10 hours per week is accurate for the first few weeks (Lab 1 and Lab 2).   After that, expect about 20 hours per week between labs and course readings.

The programming assignments are the highlight of this class. The lectures are all right. Both professors work hard, but there is way too much material in a lecture, so all of it does not sink in for me. We are expected to supplement it with the course readings from the text-book. I love that the assignments are in C since that is the only language (other than PERL) that I am acquainted with. The newsgroup is invaluable.
The previous reviewer is correct in that the specifications for the projects are not complete but that is how it is in the real world. I guess the onus is on the student to ask the right questions, do some research and fill in the gaps. The pop-quizzes are irritating. The 5-10 hours per week is a bit deceptive. As a EE guy, used to doing pen and paper assignments I found the old learning curve pretty steep and had to spend 15-20 hrs a week just on the assignments. Factor in the course readings and it is another 3 to 4 hours of good clean fun.

I feel the same as poster below (taking it right now). It's almost as if they didn't take into consideration the concerns of students:

1) The entire class is in C, which is unnecessary. We're not here to learn how to program the most *efficient* networking classes, but to learn how to program them, period. So much effort is wasted dealing with C's idiosyncrasies. This, however, is a complaint that's pretty subjective.

2) The tutorials are horrid. Literally 50% of the time will be spent scouring the newsgroup for information that should have been included in the handout (not to mention, essential bits of information are dispersed among header files, .c files, and web pages). PLEASE consolidate this for our sanity!

3) The lectures are good. But the pop quizzes, come on. Some of us prefer to watch at home at 1.7x speed. Since we're no longer in the 4th grade, perhaps one could respect this decision. The only reason to force people to come to class is to play to the speaker's ego (who doesn't want a filled classroom?). Let's stick to letting students learn how they may.

I have mixed feelings about this class. It was definitely a cool class, in that you could only complete the exams if you really did understand what is going on. Subsequently, it's also cool because you learn what's going on in the internet, and why things work the way they do.

However, every assignment was a bit frustrating. The assignment descriptions weren't very detailed, so a substantial amount of time went into just figuring out what it is you need to do. Also the starter code was pretty messy. They'd use different variable types for the SAME thing at different parts of the starter code (e.g. unsigned int vs uint32_t)

This class reminded me of 140 because there was so much material across such a wide spectrum of topics. Exams are open note, but you really need to understand the topics before going into the exam, otherwise it won't help you much.

There were also 4pop quizzesat the start of randomly chosen lectures to keep people coming to class, but the content wasn't trivial either.

The programming assignments were definitely easier than 140's and are all in C. Most of it felt like I was just casting packet bits into their respective header stucts and manipulating some bits. Not super exciting stuff.

After this class, you'll know how computer networks work at a pretty detailed level, and as such, I thought it was worth taking. This is definitely not for out-of-major people looking to learn how the Internet works though.

This is a good computer networking course. I had a lot of experience with the course material before, so the topics were not really new. However, they were clearly presented and it helped me to better understand most of the suite of networking protocols that we use daily. The course will be changing a little next year I hear, so I can't comment too much on the assignments' length or complexity. You basically get to write a client, a server, a transport protocol, and a simple router in C, and then a dynamic router in Java. Everyone knows C is a pain and that was most of my gripe about this class. I guess it's good to know how to do it... but it's painful to write.  Any case, if you're interested in networking you will like this class. Also recommended: CS155 as a corequisite... to keep your code and protocols secure (networking people are usually not that hot at security, unfortunately).

description: Principles and practice. Structure and components of computer networks, packet switching, layered architectures. Applications: web/http, voice-over-IP, p2p file sharing and socket programming. Reliable transport: TCP/IP, reliable transfer, flow control, and congestion control. The network layer: names and addresses, routing. Local area networks: ethernet and switches. Wireless networks and network security. Prerequisite:CS 110.
name: Introduction to Computer Networking
